text:
This researcher is examining a 2-D material
under a microscope.
You may have heard of 2-D materials before.
Graphene is one.

It’s made of a single crystalline layer
of carbon atoms.
Or sometimes a few layers of atoms.

Scientists are excited about a variety of
2-D materials that are flexible and have electrical

properties that make them attractive for display
screens, wearable electronics, and energy
storage devices.

One 2-D material that researchers, including
this one, are particularly excited about is
black phosphorus.

This ultrathin material is a semiconductor,
and it has a high charge mobility, which means
that electrons move through it quickly.

The trouble with black phosphorus, though,
is that it’s tough to make large flakes
of it.

Black phosphorus also degrades quickly when
exposed to air, making it difficult to study.

So researchers at the University of Arkansas
recently made an airtight sample cell and

combined it with a fabrication technique called
hot exfoliation.

To make flakes of some of the newer 2-D materials,
researchers commonly peel them away from a
larger block of material with adhesive tape.

But this method often results in small or
less-than-pristine flakes.

Hot exfoliation, which involves heating a
peeled material to help it bond to a substrate,
can create larger flakes.

The team separated flakes of black phosphorus
using adhesive tape, then stuck the tape to
a silicon chip.

Heating the black phosphorus sandwich drives
out gas bubbles, increasing the contact area
between the sample and the chip.

When the tape is pulled away after cooling,
relatively large flakes of material remain
behind on the silicon chip for studying.

Now that the Arkansas researchers have their
large flakes of black phosphorus, they can
add them to the airtight cell they designed.

The aluminum cell has a glass window through
which researchers can image the sample.

While working inside a glove box, researchers
place a sample into the cell.

Then they screw the two halves of the cell
together, creating a seal that will maintain

an inert environment, even when removed from
the glove box.

With this combined method, the Arkansas group
was able to get larger flakes and more of
them—6 to 10 times more material than usual.

And they were able to image the flakes with
optical microscopy and polarized Raman spectroscopy
without the flakes degrading.

UC Berkeley’s Kwabena Bediako, who works
with 2-D materials, said he thinks the team’s

transfer cell is an innovative and simple
design that will be helpful for working with
air-sensitive 2-D materials.

Complete instructions for making and using
the team’s sealed transfer cell can be found
in the Journal of Visualized Experiments.
